file_content.text: [This holoterminal is offline.]
The competition is over, Master Satele. We won.
Your safe return is cause enough for celebration, but preventing the Empire from gaining new weapons is a significant victory.
The Colicoids have already begun shipping technology to our forces. You've bought us some much-needed breathing room.
Anytime, Master Satele. You can always count on me and my allies.
Glad to help.
You've proven that on more occasions than I can count.
You made it sound like these weapons were our ticket to victory.
Is that all?
Weapons are only one factor in this conflict. Nothing is ever certain.
From what I saw, the Colicoids are just as bad as the Empire. When this war's over, we'll be fighting those insects.
The Colicoids are a threat.
I sincerely hope that is not true--but I will communicate your observation to Republic High Command.
This unfortunate business is behind us, but the war goes on--as do your personal missions.
Do what you can to hold the line out there. Give our people time to regroup. May the Force be with us.
[This holoterminal is offline.]
Opening priority channel "indigo seven." I'm receiving your transmission. It's good to see you, but I'm afraid I don't have pleasant news.
The war is not going well for Republic forces. We've sustained heavy losses on multiple fronts. The Empire is too well-equipped.
And unless we take immediate action, they could gain a decisive advantage that will overwhelm us.
We've fought too hard to let the Empire beat us. I assume you have a plan?
Failure is not an option.
Not a plan--a surprise opportunity from an unexpected source.
From what I've seen, the Republic is kicking the Empire's back side. What happened?
But I thought we were winning.
This war spans dozens of systems. For every one where the Republic emerges victorious, there are three where we don't. But there is hope.
Maybe our troops need better leaders.
Time for new leadership.
We're facing practical realities. Troop numbers. Technology. We need more of both.
The Colicoids are an insectoid species who have remained neutral in the war. They're weapon merchants, selling to both sides.
They've developed devastating new weapon designs. The Republic must secure the Colicoids' technology to survive the Empire's onslaught.
It isn't enough to get these weapons for ourselves. We have to stop the Empire from acquiring them.
That's only half the solution.
Correct. You were not summoned to negotiate an arms deal.
I'm surprised to find you advocating an escalation of this destructive war.
Attacking is not the Jedi way.
Unless the Republic defends itself, this war will end all too quickly for us. It is a difficult truth we cannot ignore.
The better the weapon, the better the soldier. If we want to send the Empire packing, we need all the firepower we can get.
No arguments here.
I wish it weren't so, but our battlefield casualty reports don't lie.
I get it. You want me to meet with these Colicoids--work out a deal. Piece of flatcake, your Masterfulness. Leave it to me.
You need a negotiator.
The Colicoids have made their terms quite clear. Negotiation is not an option.
I fought some of these beasts on Balmorra. They didn't know the business end of a hydrospanner, much less how to design advanced weapons.
There are smart Colicoids?
The Colicoids on Balmorra are genetically engineered drones. True Colicoids are highly intelligent beings--and far more dangerous.
What kind of weapons are we talking about?
Describe the Colicoid tech.
It's a broad array: everything from orbital torpedo pods and droid tanks to advanced infantry shields.
The Colicoids have issued a challenge to both Republic and Empire. We are invited to a contest of military might.
The winner receives an exclusive contract to purchase the Colicoids' weapons. The loser gets nothing. The Empire has already accepted and sent forces.
Why would the Colicoids make an exclusive offer? Wouldn't they profit more from selling to both of us?
An odd bargain.
Colicoids are shrewd merchants. They know that both Republic and Empire will pay dearly for an advantage the other side cannot possess.
What exactly is this contest? How do we win--best two out of three?
What are the rules?
There are no rules. It is simply war on a battlefield created for commerce.
Why would the Republic participate in the Colicoids' sick game?
The Colicoids are insane.
We sought a more peaceful negotiation, but the Empire's agreement to their terms forced our hand.
A small strike team must enter a remote asteroid base on the Outer Rim. The Colicoids will test our battle-worthiness there.
I find the entire scenario barbaric and wasteful, but we cannot allow the Empire to acquire the Colicoid weapons unopposed.
If I've learned anything from this war, it's that the enemy won't rest until we're all dead. I'll fight this battle, Master.
We'll do what we must.
Again and again, I ask too much of you. And yet you never fail.
Using their weapons to stop the Empire can only benefit the galaxy.
Our efforts won't be wasted.
I hope when this war finally ends we'll have no further need of such terrible devices.
Havoc Squad handles details like this every day, Master Satele. If there's a battle to fight, we're there.
That's all you had to say.
Every day? I regret so many sacrifices are required of you, Captain.
Never let your competitor steal a deal. Besides, I assume the players in this little chess match get paid--right?
That wouldn't be sporting.
In addition to whatever Colicoid technology you obtain during the competition, you'll be amply rewarded by the Republic.
Is it too late to back out?
Like it or not, you rank among the Republic's greatest warriors. If you cannot win this competition, no one can.
You should go.
Twenty years ago, I would be answering the challenge. But I am no longer the warrior you are.
Be aware: The Colicoids will participate in their own contest. Killing you elevates their individual clans. They won't exercise restraint.
Your shuttle is waiting nearby--hurry. May the Force be with you.
[This holoterminal is offline.]
